javadoc:
Represents an instance of a string in a {@link MemBuffer}.

This class handles all the details of detecting a terminated string's length, converting the bytes in the membuffer into a java native String, and converting the raw String into a formatted human-readable version, according to the various {@link SettingsDefinition}s attached to the string data location.

methods.name: isString
methods.comment: Returns true if the Data instance is a 'string'.

params.name: data
params.comment: Data instance to test, null ok.

methods.name: getStringDataInstance
methods.comment: Returns a new StringDataInstance using the bytes in the data codeunit.

methods.name: getStringDataInstance
methods.comment: Returns a new StringDataInstance using the bytes in the MemBuffer.

params.name: dataType
params.comment: DataType of the bytes in the buffer.

methods.name: <init>
methods.comment:
Creates a string instance using the data in the MemBuffer and the settings
 pulled from the AbstractStringDataType.

params.name: settings
params.comment: Settings attached to the data location.

params.name: length
params.comment:
Length passed from the caller to the datatype.  -1 indicates a 'probe'
 trying to detect the length of an unknown string, otherwise it will be the length
 of the containing field of the data instance.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the string name of the charset.
@return string charset name
methods.name: getCharsetName
methods.comment: Returns the string name of the charset.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the address of the {@link MemBuffer}.
@return {@link Address} of the MemBuffer.
methods.name: getAddress
methods.comment: Returns the address of the MemBuffer.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the length of this string's data, in bytes.
@return number of bytes in this string.
methods.name: getDataLength
methods.comment: Returns the length of this string's data, in bytes.

return.comment: number of bytes in this string.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the length, in bytes, of the string data object contained in the {@link MemBuffer}, or -1 if the length could not be determined.

This is not the same as the number of characters in the string, or the number of bytes occupied by the characters. For instance, pascal strings have a 1 or 2 byte length field that increases the size of the string data object beyond the characters in the string, and null terminated strings have don't include the null character, but its presence is included in the size of the string object.

For length-specified string data types that do not use null-terminators and with a known data instance length (ie. not a probe), this method just returns the value specified in the constructor {@code length} parameter, otherwise a null-terminator is searched for.

When searching for a null-terminator, the constructor {@code length} parameter will be respected or ignored depending on the {@link StringLayoutEnum}.

When the length parameter is ignored (ie. "unbounded" searching), the search is limited to {@link #MAX_STRING_LENGTH} bytes.

The MemBuffer's endian'ness is used to determine which end of the padded character field contains our n-bit character which will be tested for null-ness. (not the endian'ness of the character set name - ie. "UTF-16BE") @return length of the string (NOT including null term if null term probe), in bytes, or -1 if no terminator found.
methods.name: getStringLength
methods.comment:
Returns the length, in bytes, of the string data object contained in the
 MemBuffer, or -1 if the length could not be determined.
 
 This is not the same as the number of characters in the string, or the number of bytes
 occupied by the characters.  For instance, pascal strings have a 1 or 2 byte length
 field that increases the size of the string data object beyond the characters in the
 string, and null terminated strings have don't include the null character, but its
 presence is included in the size of the string object.
 
 For length-specified string data types that do not use null-terminators and with a
 known data instance length (ie. not a probe), this method just returns the
 value specified in the constructor  parameter, otherwise a null-terminator
 is searched for.
 
 When searching for a null-terminator, the constructor  parameter will
 be respected or ignored depending on the StringLayoutEnum.
 
 When the length parameter is ignored (ie. "unbounded" searching), the search is
 limited to #MAX_STRING_LENGTH bytes.
 
 The MemBuffer's endian'ness is used to determine which end of the padded character
 field contains our n-bit character which will be tested for null-ness.  (not the
 endian'ness of the character set name - ie. "UTF-16BE")

return.comment:
length of the string (NOT including null term if null term probe), in bytes,
 or -1 if no terminator found.

methods.name: hasNullTerminator
methods.comment:
Returns true if the string has a trailing NULL character within the data instance's
 bounds.

return.comment: boolean true if there is a trailing NULL character.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the string contained in the specified {@link MemBuffer}, or null if all the bytes of the string could not be read.

This method deals in characters of size {@link #charSize}, that might be {@link #paddedCharSize padded} to a larger size. The raw n-byte characters are converted into a Java String using a Java {@link Charset} or by using a custom Ghidra conversion. (see convertBytesToStringCustomCharset)

The MemBuffer's endian'ness is used to determine which end of the {@link #paddedCharSize padded } field contains our {@link #charSize} character bytes which will be used to create the java String. @return String containing the characters in buf or null if unable to read all {@code length} bytes from the membuffer.
methods.name: getStringValue
methods.comment:
Returns the string contained in the specified MemBuffer, or null if
 all the bytes of the string could not be read.
 
 This method deals in characters of size #charSize, that might be
 #paddedCharSize to a larger size.  The raw n-byte characters
 are converted into a Java String using a Java Charset or by
 using a custom Ghidra conversion.  (see convertBytesToStringCustomCharset)
 
 The MemBuffer's endian'ness is used to determine which end of the
 #paddedCharSize field contains our #charSize
 character bytes which will be used to create the java String.

return.comment:
String containing the characters in buf or null if unable to read all
  bytes from the membuffer.

methods.javadoc:
Returns a formatted version of the string returned by {@link #getStringValue()}.

The resulting string will be formatted with quotes around the parts that contain plain ASCII alpha characters (and simple escape sequences), and out-of-range byte-ish values listed as comma separated hex-encoded values:

Example (quotes are part of result): {@code "Test\tstring",01,02,"Second\npart",00} @return formatted String
methods.name: getStringRepresentation
methods.comment:
Returns a formatted version of the string returned by #getStringValue().
 
 The resulting string will be formatted with quotes around the parts that contain
 plain ASCII alpha characters (and simple escape sequences), and out-of-range
 byte-ish values listed as comma separated hex-encoded values:
 
 Example (quotes are part of result):

methods.name: trimNulls
methods.comment: Trims trailing nulls off the end of the string.

return.comment: new String without any trailing null chars.

methods.name: getTranslatedValue
methods.comment:
Returns the value of the stored
 TranslationSettingsDefinition#getTranslatedValue(Settings)
 string.

methods.name: isShowTranslation
methods.comment:
Returns true if the user should be shown the translated value of the string instead
 of the real value.

return.comment: boolean true if should show previously translated value.

methods.javadoc:
Convert a char value in memory into its canonical unicode representation, using attached charset and encoding information.

This implementation treats the char value as a 1 element long string and reuses the string logic to read it from memory using charset info. @return String containing the representation of the single char.
methods.name: getCharRepresentation
methods.comment:
Convert a char value in memory into its canonical unicode representation, using
 attached charset and encoding information.
 
 This implementation treats the char value as a 1 element long string and reuses the string
 logic to read it from memory using charset info.

return.comment: String containing the representation of the single char.

methods.javadoc:
Returns a new {@link StringDataInstance} that points to the string characters that start at {@code byteOffset} from the start of this instance.

If the requested offset is not valid, the base string instance (itself) will be returned instead of a new instance.

@param byteOffset number of bytes from start of data instance to start new instance. @return new StringDataInstance, or this if offset not valid.
methods.name: getByteOffcut
methods.comment:
Returns a new StringDataInstance that points to the string characters
 that start at  from the start of this instance.
 
 If the requested offset is not valid, the base string instance (itself) will be returned
 instead of a new instance.

params.name: byteOffset
params.comment: number of bytes from start of data instance to start new instance.

return.comment: new StringDataInstance, or this if offset not valid.

methods.javadoc:
Create a new {@link StringDataInstance} that points to a portion of this instance, starting at a character offset (whereever that may be) into the data.

@param offsetChars number of characters from the beginning of the string to start the new StringDataInstance. @return new {@link StringDataInstance} pointing to a subset of characters, or the this instance if there was an error.
methods.name: getCharOffcut
methods.comment:
Create a new StringDataInstance that points to a portion of this
 instance, starting at a character offset (whereever that may be) into the data.

params.name: offsetChars
params.comment:
number of characters from the beginning of the string to start
 the new StringDataInstance.

return.comment:
new StringDataInstance pointing to a subset of characters, or the
 this instance if there was an error.

Maps a {@link StringDataInstance} (this type) to the String DataType that best can handle this type of data.

@return {@link DataType}, defaulting to {@link StringDataType} if no direct match found.
methods.name: getStringDataTypeGuess
methods.comment:
Maps a StringDataInstance (this type) to the String DataType that best
 can handle this type of data.
 
 I dare myself to type Type one more time.

return.comment: DataType, defaulting to StringDataType if no direct match found.

name: StringDataInstance
comment:
Represents an instance of a string in a MemBuffer.
 
 This class handles all the details of detecting a terminated string's length,
 converting the bytes in the membuffer into a java native String, and converting
 the raw String into a formatted human-readable version, according to the
 various SettingsDefinitions attached to the string data location.

fields.javadoc:
A {@link StringDataInstance} that represents a non-existent string.

Methods on this instance generally return null.
fields.name: NULL_INSTANCE
fields.comment:
A StringDataInstance that represents a non-existent string.
 
 Methods on this instance generally return null.

fields.javadoc: A string with a single char that is the Byte-Order-Mark character.
fields.name: BOM_RESULT_STR
fields.comment: A string with a single char that is the Byte-Order-Mark character.

fields.javadoc:
Maps a {@link StringDataInstance}'s layout and charset info into the best String DataType that can handle this type of data instance.

An entry with a null charset name is equivalent to any charset.
fields.name: dataTypeMap
fields.comment:
Maps a StringDataInstance's layout and charset info into the best String
 DataType that can handle this type of data instance.
 
 An entry with a null charset name is equivalent to any charset.
